abstracts.cdata!:
The Agriculture Sector Management
            Support Project's overall outcome is rated as
            satisfactory. However, some outcomes were only partially
            achieved, particularly there is a question over political
            commitment - as evidenced by the failure to carry through on
            intentions in resource allocation, and by breakdown of the
            training management system. Moreover, staff trained may not
            be available or willing to work as expected given the low
            pay and poor working conditions in the civil service.
            Lessons learned from this project include: Complexity is a
            relative concept that can change as project agencies acquire
            skills. National ownership is vital in a capacity building
            project, but such a project can also build ownership.
            Institutional development is a longer term challenge than
            capacity building. Every means possible should be sought to
            ensure national ownership and control of technical
            assistance. Close supervision of capacity building projects
            brings results. Crisis can produce beneficial change, if a
            flexible approach can be taken. With regard to Yemen, civil
            service is unlikely to be high yielding under existing
            incentive framework. The budget problem has yet to be resolved.
